B000002R9X|5.0|Gentle Giant is one of the most interesting progressive rock bands that has ever been.  From 1970 to 1980, they put out some of the most provacative, fascinating, and musically complex music in progressive rock.  In the middle of their career, they put out a release calle &quot;Free Hand&quot;.<br />Free Hand: Arguably their most popular album (with the possible exception of &quot;In a Glass House&quot;), and certainly one of their best! It was released in 1972, and is their third recording. The first track, &quot;Just the Same&quot;, starts with the snapping of fingers, making a nice tempo, and it is then accompanied by a keyboard rhythm, and electric guitar, and then explodes into a heavy bass, drums, and vocals: &quot;See me, What I am, What I was, What I'll be....&quot;, as Derek Shulman belts out the lyrics in his inimitable style (and subtlety accompanied by strange saxophones, clarinets, and horns). Changes and more changes, musically, rhythmically, and in time and tempo, abound throughout this catchy, strangely mellow, and at times, heavy, and excellent song.<br />The second track is called &quot;On Reflection&quot;, and is one that continues to display the unexpected virtousity, and inventiveness, and talent of Gentle Giant. It is a song in which all five members of the group sing, in a juxtaposed harmony that is reminiscent of Medieval English minstrel music. Lovely! (Especially Kerry Minnear's soft vocals in the middle of this song).<br />The third track, and title track, is &quot;Free Hand&quot;, and is my favorite song on this recording. This one is really powerful! Back is the driving bass guitar work of Ray Shulman, and the excellent guitar work of Gary Green. Also on this song are all the unexpected changes in tempo, it is like 4 or 5 songs in one!<br />The fourth track is &quot;Time to Kill&quot;, and starts with the sounds from the original computer game, &quot;Pong&quot;. A medium level Giant song, it does groove in it's own way.<br />The fifth track is &quot;His Last Voyage&quot;, and begins with a mellow bass line, compliment by vibes and guitar, and then melding perfectly into a lovely vocal harmony, with Minnear in the lead. This is a very dreamy song, and quite ethereal.<br />The sixth track is entitled &quot;Talybont&quot;, is an instrumental piece, and is another of my favorite songs on this album. Again, it displays that hard-to-put-your-finger-on-quality and medieval feel that much of Gentle Giant's music is famous for.<br />It comes complete with harpsichord, electric guitar and bass, recorder, moog synthesizers, flute, tambourine, and drums.<br />The seventh, and final track on this recording is &quot;Mobile&quot;, and this exhibits the kind of driving, 'rolling' heavy bass lines, raucous vocals of Derek Shulman, and soft keyboard/harpsichord work of Minnear, eclectic electric guitar work of Gary Greene, fantastic drumming of John Weathers. It is also complete and replete with the strangeness and altogether weirdness of Gentle Giant. At times, it is like they are 'punk classical', from Mozart's time, especially when the bass player, Ray Shulman, pulls out his electric violin, and has a go in the middle of the song!<br />So, by all means, stretch the limits of your imagination, and expand your musical horizons with the boundless possibilities of Gentle Giant!rack is &quot;His Last Voyage&quot;, and begins with a mellow bass line, compliment by vibes and guitar, and then melding perfectly into a lovely vocal harmony, with Minnear in the lead. This is a very dreamy song, and quite ethereal. <br />The sixth track is entitled &quot;Talybont&quot;, is an instrumental piece, and is another of my favorite songs on this album. Again, it displays that hard-to-put-your-finger-on-quality and medieval feel that much of Gentle Giant's music is famous for.<BR>It comes complete with harpsichord, electric guitar and bass, recorder, moog synthesizers, flute, tambourine, and drums. <br />The seventh, and final track on this recording is &quot;Mobile&quot;, and this exhibits the kind of driving, 'rolling' heavy bass lines, raucous vocals of Derek Shulman, and soft keyboard/harpsichord work of Minnear, eclectic electric guitar work of Gary Greene, fantastic drumming of John Weathers. It is also complete and replete with the strangeness and altogether weirdness of Gentle Giant. At times, it is like they are 'punk classical', from Mozart's time, especially when the bass player, Ray Shulman, pulls out his electric violin, and has a go in the middle of the song!<br />So, by all means, stretch the limits of your imagination, and expand your musical horizons with the boundless possibilities of Gentle Giant!

B00005OM4N|5.0|\\"Britney,\\" Spears' third album in which 19 year old entertainer fights the system and struggles to expand the musical boundaries of the close-minded pop music scene and emerges successful. Though the lyrical content sometimes seems to contradict itself, the lyrics that many critics question for being contradictory of each other are not actually the lyrics on the album written by Britney. For a more personal portrait of the real Britney Spears, check out the self-portrait \\"Let Me Be.\\" It's Britney's truest statement yet, in which she sings \\"Sorry if I sound confused, or don't feel the way you do, but I won't turn around.\\" She may not be a woman, but she knows what she wants and she's going to get it no matter what. Other highlights of the album are Britney's excellent experiments with the hip hop uber-producers, The Neptunes, such as the fascinating, grinding first single, \\"I'm A Slave 4 U\\" and the danceable and catchy \\"Boys.\\" Spears shows inspiration from Janet Jackson with the edgy syncopation of \\"Lonely\\" and the disco beats of \\"Anticipating,\\" both co-written by the singer. Britney takes the pop beats of her past to the next level with the powerful \\"Overprotected,\\" the infectious \\"Bombastic Love,\\" and the Spears co-written epic \\"Cinderella.\\" Spears shows her softer side in \\"That's Where You Take Me,\\" with the lyrics of a girl in love with... Justin Timberlake who co-wrote the bombastic \\"What It's Like To Be Me\\" with choreographer Wade J. Robson, in which Timberlake adds background vocals that make the song sound more like a duet than anything else. Unfortunately, the couple is now estranged and this collaboration may never have the chance to exist again. Spears' cover of the Joan Jett classic \\"I Love Rock 'N' Roll,\\" sleek and sexy takes the hook of the original to an new level. But the album's highlight is \\"I'm Not A Girl, Not Yet A Woman,\\" Spears' first truly strong ballad, which she finally has the vocal prowess to interpret in an exciting way (co-written by MaxMartin and Dido). In the spotlight, we have all watched Britney Spears grow from naieve teenager to the twenty year old almost-woman she is today. Some critics blame this album for making a schizophrenic musical statement, but thats half the fun. Spears takes influences from many different musical styles and makes them her own in a fascinating and exciting way. Her vocal strength and power of interpretation carry this album throughout. You can hear that Spears relates to each song well, making this album a deeply personal statement. In a word, this album is \\"Britney,\\" but you already knew that.

B00001OH7X|4.0|Lodger, the third of the Bowie/Eno trilogy is more reflective of Bowie's style than the more collaborative efforts of Heroes and Low. The sound with its constantly driving percussion and the vagulely African/Middle Eastern rhythms creates a hypnotic feel that captures the listener. But when focus shifts to Bowie's typically distant lyrics, this CD becomes a triumph of style over substance. A little more substance and this could have been one of Bowie's best, as it is it is well worth your time.
0671027344|5.0|This is a deeply moving story about Charlie--a high school freshman struggling to come to terms with himself and his place in the world.  This novel simply sucks the reader into Charlie's world--the sadness, the pain, and yes the exhilaration of &quot;being infinite.&quot;        <BR>The entire story is cleverly presented in letter form with Charlie pouring out his feelings to an unidentified person he simply calls &quot;friend.&quot;  This format succeeds because Charlie's words come across as raw, heartfelt, and sincere--at times beautifully so, at other times, heartbreakingly so.
B00004W5UA|4.0|Fight Club is about a man, known only as the Narrator, (Edward Norton) who hates his boring life and has to find alternative ways to deal with his misery.  One of the ways he copes is by becoming a tourist, but not in a traditional sense.  This kind of tourist is someone who attends support groups even though he/she doesn't have any disease or affliction.  He goes to support group meetings because he likes the coffee, the folded chairs, the crying, the sharing of feelings.  He likes feeling special for once.  The whole premise of this type of &quot;tourism&quot; has black humor value, but the film's handling of these scenes (especially the deadly unfunny topic of cancer) is more dumb than funny or really black for that matter.  <br />While at a support group, he meets Marla (Helena Bonham Carter), another tourist.  She looks like a heroin addict, wears the blackest make up one can wear without looking Goth, and dresses in clothes that were &quot;once owned by the victim of a sex crime.&quot;  Marla hates life like the Narrator, but copes with it by becoming suicidal and self- destructive, unlike the Narrator who becomes violent- a pretty clear statement about male and female aggression.  While women take it out on themselves, men take it out on each other.  But that's pretty much all one can say to describe Marla.  She has no ambition, no motivation, and she doesn't really do anything.  Marla is truly a nothing character, despite Helena Bonham Carter's fascinating performance.  Her purpose is solely to gratuitously have sex and round out the edges of the plot.   <br />After his apartment mysteriously burns down, the Narrator decides to call a soap salesman he met on a plane named Tyler Durden (Brad Pitt).  He finds that Tyler is everything that he wants to be but can't.  Tyler is muscular and good looking in a rugged way as opposed to Edward Norton's sniveling dweeb.  Tyler works at his own pace; the Narrator sees himself as a white-collar slave.  Tyler lives in a dilapidated house, an utter contrast to the Narrator's former IKEA shrine.  Tyler is everything anti-consumerism, anti- greed, anti-conformity.  After their first meeting, Tyler says something to the Narrator thatsurprises him.  &quot;Hit me&quot; he says.  The two then get into a fight, find the experience exhilarating, and start a literal &quot;fight club&quot; in the basement of Tyler's dilapidated house.  Soon, scores of men across the unnamed city they live in start showing up to beat each other up.<br />The basic message I got from this film is that when men feel they aren't allowed to work out their aggressions, they become violent and insane.  The target in this film is consumerism and conformity in the work place, which threaten a man's masculinity.  Consumerism, according to Tyler, is the artificial hunter-gatherer sense of worth, and thus picks apart the biological foundation which gives worth to the male mind.  To compensate for this confusion and subsequent loss of masculinity, these men need to beat each other up and get beaten up to feel the rugged pain that they've been denied their lives.<br />A question I found myself repeatedly asking was, could someone actually &quot;enjoy&quot; breaking their nose, punching their teeth out, and getting stitches?  The purpose is to show the EXTREMES of male frustration, but it would have been better had David Fincher had actually made the violence glamorous.  As it stands, the violence is graphic enough to be unwatchable, but also too unrealistic to take seriously (no one can kick and punch someone in the jaw repeatedly without breaking it in some way).  Or maybe, just maybe, Fincher didn't have to show the violence at all.  How brilliant would a movie with the main theme of violence be if it didn't have a lot of actual violence in it?  Also if violence and mayhem is a common goal among men, how come most war veterans find themselves in trauma and shock at the evils of their own violence?  And why don't these menenroll in<br />the army if they enjoy pointless violence so much?  Though any movie that generates heavy discussion, is, by default, interesting, most of the questions Fight Club conjures are provoked about the basis of why the movie was made to explore these themes, not about the actual content itself.  Thus it doesn't constitute as sufficient ambiguity. <br />Finally, the twist ending.  Although surprising and cool, not that much of interest happens before then.  However, the twist is so cool in fact, that I was almost tempted to forget how much I didn't enjoy the movie up to that point.  Consider it a great ending to a sorely misguided movie.

Anyway, this release would be the last of a great legacy of thrash metal.  They were the kings.  Were...<br />This is how I like to remember them.  Not as revolutionary as &quot;Master Of Puppets&quot; and not as ground breaking as &quot;Kill em All and Ride the Lightning&quot;, but still an example of what metal used to be when money wasn't the ONLY thing on ones mind. B000000H6D|5.0|Now, the difference between this release of Bloody Kisses and the original release of BK (ASIN: B000000H6Y) is that they cut out all the punky/speed metal type tunes and added one really long and beautiful song about the horror of being a vampire.  If you're more on the &quot;gothy&quot; side and you have no patience for fast rock, then I recommend getting this release.  However, I have to say I like the original better as it is more balanced and emotional.  But, it's still an excellent album and one of my faves!! Then one day I heard &quot;Black No. 1&quot; on the radio one day and I thought &quot;This is brilliant&quot;. A song that makes so much fun of the whole goth culture, yet perfectly captured the dark, autumny, vampiric feel of the whole goth music scene. And they do it very well. When I found out it was Type-O I suddenly had a new found respect for a group of guys that had a fairly wide range of styles (if you call rock, punk and goth varied) and ALSO had the ability to execute all of them perfectly.<br />Peter Steele's voice is very unique and really gives a creepy feel to all the songs whether they be fast, slow or really slow. Reminds me a lot of The Swans. In fact it wouldn't suprise me AT ALL if The Swans were a major influence on the switch of styling that they've undertaken with this release. This is a great (debut?) into what would be a serious of very dark and emotional, yet funny and wild, CD's that really stand tall as a Tribute Of Excellence (a Headstone, maybe) for when Type-O are no more.<br />Once more, if you are at all into &quot;dark, slow and heavy&quot; music then you won't like any of Type-O's earlier releases. They're good, but they're nothing like Bloody Kisses, October Rust and World Coming Down.
0345413377|4.0|That this series is beautifully written and vibrantly conceived, I cannot deny. I was so enthralled with this last volume that I couldn't put it down -- despite being at a noisy party, I read for two hours until I finished. Pullman's worlds are complex, his philosophy sophisticated, and his characters endearing.<br />That being said, I felt this volume lacked the tight writing of the previous two. I was disappointed with the fruition of the prophecy from the earlier works -- despite the build-up, Lyra's &quot;temptation&quot; is one common to all people. Worse, however, Pullman's critique of the church became positively knee-jerk in parts, undermining his credibility. Church members seemed to have little motivation for their cruel and brutal actions; they became flat, two-dimensional villains, not people. One priest/assassin character got almost no narrative time except to A) stalk the protagonists and B) think about convincing the peaceful wheeled people that their very way of life is Satanic. Pullman may have been trying to demonstrate that the life-denying quality of the church pervades it, but that particular comment seemed unmotivated and contrived -- essentially a pot-shot.<br />Overall, I am very sympathetic to Pullman's brand of spirituality, but I feel he undermines his cause somewhat by demonizing religion in such a categorical way. Liberal religious people today are engaged in taking back religious language from fundamentalists. Many use the word &quot;God&quot; to describe that immanent spirit of life that Pullman portrays as being opposed to the church. By setting up worlds in which &quot;God&quot; can only be the patriarchal, hierarchical head of a spiritual hegemony, Pullman makes the task of those committed to making religion meaningful again even harder than it already is.<br />As a work of fiction, there's not much to fault in this series. But I do think it's a shame that the chip Pullman has on his shoulder with regards to Christianity leads him to alienate some of the religious people who would otherwise be his natural allies.o alienate some of the religious people who would otherwise be his natural allies.

0887306101|5.0|I first read this book in 1991 and I was so pumped up that I read it again a year later.  The tales of these professionals kept me riveted and the relaxed, conversational style of the book makes it an easy read.  I learned several of my most hard-and-fast disciplines from this book (&quot;cut your losses, let your winners run&quot;, &quot;know your 'uncle' point&quot;, &quot;have patience to wait for the right trade to come along&quot;).  Favorite interviews were Michael Marcus, Paul Tudor Jones, Ed Seykota, Larry Hite, William O'Neil and Jim Rogers.  Surprisingly, what you gather from the compilation of interviews is that despite a focus on different investment time horizons or securities, there are common keys to success across most of these guys, many of whom achieved legendary status.  I came away from this book realizing that you must take these well-established rules and apply them in a disciplined fashion to your personal investment style.  You will not be good at all things (stocks, options, commodities, shorting, etc.).  So, find what your personal strength is and apply these disciplines to achieve success.  I still make investing mistakes (believe me!).  But I've made a lot fewer of them because of the lessons I learned from this book.  Three other points:<br />1)  This book turned me on to Reminiscences of a Stock Operator, my all-time favorite book about the markets (check it out in Amazon).<BR>2)  The book is a bit dated, so some of the people (e.g., Robert Prechter) and newsletters (e.g., Zweig Letter) referenced by the interviewees are no longer around or have lost status.<BR>3)  The New Market Wizards falls short of the standard set by this book, but the sequel is still probably worth reading.
0553106635|5.0|I've read some of the reviews that others have written and it seems to me they keep saying the same thing: GRRM doesn't mind killing off main characters. I say this is wrong. The characters he kills off--while enagaging and very interesting in themselves--would never play a part in the battles with the Others, which is why it doesn't hinder the story to kill them off...the fact that he makes you love these otherwise minor characters, and care what happens to them just shows what a great developer of characters he is. It's all so subtle, so sneaky, and oh so brilliant.

B000059T5O|4.0|The reviews herein lead me to believe that the Waits fans don't know much about Hammond and vice versa and the two groups have entirely different takes on this collection. The Hammond fans seem to think it's good blues while the Waits fans aren't too sure what's going on here.<BR>I fall into the latter group. I've listened to Waits since 1975 and have watched his stylistic evolution while marveling that the more he changes the more he remains the same.  The acerbically romantic worldview pervades the Asylum albums, the Frank's Wild Years musings, and the &quot;post-Frank&quot; material that seems to synthesize much of what has gone before.<BR>All this background makes me wonder if Waits isn't putting us on here and laughing at what the public will accept. I basically like this album, but I can't help picturing Wayne Newton in the vocal spotlight, with Waits and his back-alley band churning up the underworld behind the curtain.  The covers of a wide range of Waits' music sound like Waits arrangements, but with a lounge lizard vocalist. Even darker musings like &quot;Jockey Full of Bourbon&quot; and &quot;Buzz Fledderjohn&quot; come across with something like a Bossa Nova flair. The tune that seems to best fit this soft-rock formula is the first one, &quot;2:19,&quot; which I don't recall hearing anywhere else.<BR>A lot of performers in diverse genres have successfully interpreted Waits' music, but they usually overdramatize it compared with the often spare original. Check out Paul Young's overwrought &quot;Soldier's Things&quot; or Rod Stewart's lush &quot;Downtown Train&quot; and compare them to the originals. By contrast, on this album drama seems to take a back seat to understanding the lyrics.<BR>So, I wonder what's going on here, but I expect that's the point. Waits' music seems to stand up to almost any treatment, so if you like Waits (or Hammond) buy &quot;Wicked Grin&quot; and listen to it a lot. You'll probably wonder too, but it's worth it.

B00003CX6P|5.0|THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY is one of those rare films that make you truly appreciate the fine art that moviemaking can be. By now, you who are reading this already know the basic story: Set in the 1950's, a young drifter from New York by the name of Tom Ripley (played to subtle but intense perfection by the talented Matt Damon) befriends, and insinuates himself into the lives of, rich spoiled Dickie Greenleaf (Jude Law) and his girlfriend Marge (Gwyneth Paltrow) in coastal Italy after being sent there by Dickie's rich industrialist father. Mr. Greenleaf merely wants his slacker son to come back to New York and take a managerial position in his company, but Tom has different plans which gradually become more and more revealed during the first half of the film. Dickie doesn't want to come back to the States, anyway; he's having far too much fun with his new friend Tom, who introduced himself as someone Dickie knew while at Princeton University. While Dickie never fully believed this story, Tom somehow intrigues him with his many abilities, such as with languages, and his quiet and irrespressible charm. The main benefit Tom provides Dickie with is male companionship, which becomes a source of shame to the promiscuously bisexual Dickie, who cheats on his would-be fiance` with members of both sexes. In the meantime, the fully homosexual Tom develops an obsessive crush on Dickie.  When Dickie begins to rebuff him, Tom learns quickly how to use his friend's philanderous ways to his own advantage. How he does this you may already know by now, but what makes THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY so engrossing is not merely the events that play out, but how each character's flaws play off of each other, and how the situation gradually snowballs to a conclusion that is as unavoidable as it is unpalatable.<br />The events of this story also involve intriguing supporting characters that are played by the always-uniquely-cast Philip Seymour Hoffman (who has built up his film career with impressive supporting roles in successful films such as TWISTER and BOOGIE NIGHTS to FLAWLESS, ALMOST FAMOUS, and now this film) and the always-appealing Cate Blanchett (as radiant here as she was in ELIZABETH). They help round out the flavor of the film as well as helping to create some of the more pivotal moments in it.<br />This film is an intensive period character study that presents a time and a place where urges were joyfully pursued but always hidden, and were never, ever discussed in public. Plus, the film's breathtaking scenes, which were shot on location in places like coastal Genoa, the ruins of ancient Rome, and the canals of Venice, provide a perfect backdrop for these characters and their decadent, not-quite-liberated lifestyles.<br />Anthony Minghella, who wrote and directed this movie, adapted Patricia Highsmith's novel far more successfully than he did THE ENGLISH PATIENT, which I found to be quite ponderous in certain areas. Although it didn't win nearly as many Oscars, THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY never gives you the feeling that it's straying off its central plot. However, you never feel like you know exactly what's going to come next during any given scene.  This movie is so well constructed that you just HAVE to stay with it to find out how it all turns out. When you do, you are rewarded with a conclusion that is both disturbing and real, and certainly does not feel contrived by any means. If only 'true stories' presented on film had as much of a mastery and understanding of human emotions; then we'd have more films that are as transfixing as this one is!<br />Definite recommendation to buy.
0780020685|5.0|The Seven Samurai proves to new generations how magnificent director was Akira Kurosawa. <BR>I can easily tell that it wont be interested for me to watch &quot;The Seven Samurai&quot; if I only read the topic of it. B00003CX9E|5.0|I have seen all the works that are done under the sun; and indeed, all is vanity and grasping for the wind. Ecclesiastes 1:14 <br />I have put off reviewing Citizen Kane for quite some time, as it seems to be so oft praised that it is almost impossible to be objective about it. Everybody knows something about Citizen Kane - even folks who have never seen it know that it is a classic, perhaps the classic - the best film ever made. How do you go about describing the Holy Grail of cinema without sounding like the usual sycophantic hack, grinding out his two cents worth of pulp on a movie that has already had more written about it than any other? <br />It would probably help to remember that in 1941 the power of the newspapers was much greater than is evident today with television, cable, the Internet, and all the alternative means of communication we have at our fingertips. In those days, the newspaper was it - the only other major information source was the newsreels that accompanied Saturday movies - newsreels like the one that is used early in Citizen Kane to give a brief sketch of the deceased's life. Newspaper magnate Charles Foster Kane was dead and the questions on everybody's lips were, &quot;Who was Kane?&quot; &quot;Why was Kane?&quot; and &quot;What did he mean by 'Rosebud' (his dying word)?&quot; If you watch the movie looking for answers to these questions, you are bound to come away dissatisfied as it answers them incompletely or not at all. <br />Rather than recount the story which is so well known, or elaborate on the innovative techniques used in filming Citizen Kane, I thought it would be interesting to find out why Welles chose newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst as the model for the fictional Kane. What would be Welles' motivation to attack a public figure who had done him no wrong? Not only that, but why would he attack somebody with the power of the press at his beck and call, someone who could (and likely would) strike back. My research along those lines only revealed tantalizing snippets of information, not enough to satisfy my curiosity. Still, it has been well documented that Welles was a guy who liked controversy and William Randolph Hearst was a juicy target. Perhaps Citizen Kane is a great film because it is enigmatic, it doesn't give any easy answers. Therefore, my inquiry bore little fruit... <br />Kane is the story of a man who gained everything, but at the cost of being deprived of his mother's love and companionship. An early scene shows him being separated from his mother and sent back east to live with a banker after his mother comes into a considerable fortune. From there, it shows the rise of a newspaper publisher and fall of a man who wound up dying friendless and alone in his palatial mansion &quot;Xanadu.&quot; What happened? When asked, Welles himself could not explain how Kane's dying word came to the knowledge of the reporter. However despite that little mystery, the movie has quite a bit of appeal. <br />Kane's story is told via flashbacks (No, Quentin Tarantino did not invent them!) from five different points of view. A faceless newspaper reporter asks Kane's closest associates to tell their recollections of him. The reporter's questions provide the springboard for each of the flashbacks. <br />Camera work and lighting by Gregg Toland used a technique called 'deep focus.' This, unlike conventional focus, allowed both foreground and background to be in razor-sharp focus at the same time allowing the viewer to decide which part of the scene to fasten his attention on. Lights and darks are used to depict the moods, light when happy, dark when depressed. Unusual camera angles abound and a number of scenes are long takes without editing. Voices, like in many of Welles' films, are often dubbed, allowing Welles to stage shots and insert and overlap dialog similar to actual human conversation. Great film editing by Robert Wise offered many dissolves, montages, and startling effects notoften seen before. These and other techniques used in Citizen Kane are textbook examples used to demonstrate good film making today. <br />The final scene of Kane shows Xanadu's basement, a vast landscape of possessions, the remains of Kane's mortal existence. Workers are classifying it, stacking it, and loading the junk into a furnace. By this time the alert viewer knows the 'book answer' to the reporter's question, &quot;What is Rosebud,&quot; however, while the film offers this obvious meaning, according to some reports it was William Randolph Hearst's pet term for his mistress' most private part. The camera pulls back and shows the smoke (the remembrance of Kane) from the furnace billowing from the castle's chimney. <br />While nominated for nine academy awards, Kane won only for Best Screenplay, a collaboration between Herman Mankiewicz and Welles. Kane was the high water mark of Welles' success as a director. Due to backlash from Hearst and his powerful friends Welles was never allowed the luxury of such creative control again. <br />What does it profit a man to gain the world and lose his soul? <br />Citizen Kane should be required viewing by anybody interested in film. It shows the results of a prodigal life with many material benefits yet yielding very little spiritual fruit.

B00005ALP6|5.0|&quot;My Fair Lady&quot; is the legendary director George Cukor's crowning achievement.   Every element of this movie works, from its sumptuous photography by veteran cameraman Harry Stradling, to the glorious costumes and sets created by Cecil Beaton.  The music is incomparable.  Frederick Loewe's melodies are lovely and infectious and Alan Jay Lerner's lyrics are every bit as witty and touching as the dialogue originally written by playwright George Bernard Shaw for &quot;Pygmalion&quot;.  &quot;My Fair Lady&quot; is the musical version of &quot;Pygmalion&quot;.<br />The transformation of the illiterate, unwashed Eliza Doolittle into the breathtaking &quot;Fair Lady&quot; of the film's title is inspiring to see.  This is one of Audrey Hepburn's best roles, and she is perfection as Eliza Doolittle.  She is thoroughly convincing as the Cockney flower girl who transcends her humble roots to end up dancing with a prince at an embassy ball. Hepburn expertly translates Eliza's tenacity, vulnerbility, intelligence, and grace into a beautiful and timeless performance.<br />Yes, it's true that Julie Andrews (who created the original Eliza on Broadway) was bypassed for this role.  However, this was purely a business decision made by studio head Jack Warner.  He did not want to risk such a lavish, expensive production on a relative newcomer such as Andrews was at the time.  So he went with the safe bet, Hepburn, as Eliza Doolittle.  Audrey was an established star with a great track record.<br />But Andrews soon recovered from this disappointment to make two blockbusters of her own, &quot;Mary Poppins&quot; and &quot;Sound of Music&quot;.  Not a bad trade-off I'd say.<br />Anyway, I enthusiastically recommend that you buy &quot;My Fair Lady&quot; on DVD or VHS.  It is one of the best musicals ever written for stage or screen.  You'll see what I mean.

0380796090|4.0|This is my favorite of the three Marian Keyes novels I've read.<br />  Keyes' humor is a little dark, but quirky and uncompromising.  She's great at describing real life frustrations. Her heroines are always strong and have a warped sense of humor.  I love the introduction to Claire's family. Every character in Claire's family is wonderfully drawn.<br />However, I could not understand why Claire's husband, James, had an affair and acted as he did.  I didn't feel like I understood his character or motivations at all.  At least if he's going to act like a jerk, have the reason be fairly credible.<br />I am seeing a trend where Marian Keyes' stories follow the same basic storyline.  Fairly attractive heroine involved in crisis, must rebuild her life or meet challenge.  Her life and the people in it no longer look the same.  Everpresent male friend/boyfriend eventually steps forward for relationship.  Heroine renews life.<br />This story is a pageturner, but still in the Marian Keyes way-- predictable.  And I don't always appreciate Keyes' humor, which is sometimes too wry for me.<br />If you like this storyline check out the 1986 movie Heartburn with Meryl Streep and Jack Nicholson.<br />Autobiographical novel is by Nora Ephron, who was briefly married to and had two sons with Washington Post journalist Carl Bernstein of Watergate fame.  Deftly directed by Mike Nichols.  Kevin Spacey can also be spotted in his first feature film role.

Waits plays and sings on a good part of it, so it's really a Tom Waits / John Hammond collaboration.  Recording quality is outstanding. Bottom line?  This is a fantastic CD.

B000002JSR|3.0|Since its release in 1982, Coda, a collection of outtakes from Led Zeppelin's legendary career, has been slammed by critics and fans alike who felt the work was sub par for the seminal British hard rock band. It is true that there are few songs on Coda that live-up to the standards set by Zeppelin's eight albums, which probably explains why they are outtakes.<br />Listeners have been unfair to Coda by judging it by the standards of other Led Zeppelin albums. It was not meant to have the impact of those releases. Coda was compiled strictly for Zeppelin's diehard fans; to save them the from attempting to accumulate the band's entire body of work through expensive bootlegs. Although, it is certainly weaker than most of Led Zeppelin's albums, as a one of many serious Zeppelin acolytes, I appreciate the gaps filled by Coda.<br />Side A presents some excellent tracks from 1969 and 70, back when Led Zeppelin were young, boisterous bluesrockers. \\"Poor Tom\\" is a hypnotically melodic, jangley footstomper; \\"We're Gonna Groove\\" exemplifies the enthralling, scrambling guitar style of early Jimmy Page and the energetic cover of Willie Dixon's \\"I Can't Quit You Babe,\\" recorded during a 1970 rehearsal, surpasses the version of the tune on their self-entitled debut.<br />The second side does not fair as well. It features lumbering hard rock songs recorded for Led Zeppelin's final album, 1979's In Through the Out Door, that were abandoned when the band decided to adopt a synthesizer-infused sound for the album. Some of the songs indicate why they felt a change in style was necessary. \\"Wearing and Tearing\\" and \\"Darlene\\" are like many songs on 1977's Presence, in that they are not necessarily poor songs, but they show enough sloppiness and predictability to indicate that the band could not blaze through a rollicking tune as masterfully as they use to. \\"Bonzo's Montreaux,\\" a \\"Moby Dick\\"-ish, extended drum solo that was recorded for Presence, also falls flat.<br />The only noteworthy track on the second side is \\"Ozone Babe,\\" an exceptional, hook-slinging rocker that features the entire band in full action. Leadsinger, Robert Plant's flirtatious choruses bounce off the band's crunching, relentless riff rocking with considerable grace, energy and charm. It is one of the best songs of the band's latter years and, if not for Coda, it would have been lost because of the band's change in style for their final album. Songs like \\"Ozone Babe\\" explain why diehard fans treasure-hunt through artists' unreleased material and also why Led Zeppelin has so many diehard fans.
B00005Q66T|5.0|This is a great album to have, or buy someone for the holidays. It's also perfect for those haters that didn't keep up in the 90's. This will turn out to be a wonder pop catalog album. I highly recommend it. Madonna's Drowned World Tour is a awesome as well.

B00004ZAV3|5.0|Baby boomers who have lovingly collected all of the Beatles original albums on cd will have little real need for &quot;Beatles One,&quot; but the fact that this includes, in chronological order, at least one side of each of the Beatles' records that reached number one on the singles charts makes it fun to listen to and an attractive &quot;extra&quot; for any Beatles collection.<br />People complain that the cd does not necessarily include the Beatles' &quot;best&quot; songs.  Hey, it's not claiming to do so, and besides, the group produced so few &quot;clinkers&quot; that any &quot;best of the Beatles&quot; selection would necessarily have to span multiple cd's. Critics also point out that some of the most excellent b sides to the Beatles' many two-sided hits have been excluded.  It's definitely a shame that &quot;Strawberry Fields Forever&quot; (the other side of &quot;Penny Lane&quot;), &quot;I am the Walrus&quot; (the flip side of &quot;Hello, Goodbye&quot;), &quot;Rain&quot; (the b side of &quot;Paperback Writer&quot;), and &quot;Please, Please Me&quot; (the other side of &quot;From Me To You&quot;) are not included.  But consider that as it stands, this cd is over 79 minutes long and hence presses up against the limits to what a cd disc can possibly hold (eighty minutes or so).  Whereas some of these exlusionary choices might have been based upon a flip of a coin, the compilers of this cd probably axed &quot;Strawberry Fields&quot; and &quot;Walrus&quot; simply because they are relatively lengthy pieces as top forty fare goes.  <br />The one complaint raised in some reviews that I think is valid relates to the bizarre stereo mastering done on a few of the tracks, most notably &quot;Daytripper&quot; and &quot;We Can Work it Out.&quot;  Pushing the lead vocal way over to one channel and relegating the entire instrumental accompaniment to the other side is a horrible and unnatural way to present any song.  If remastering was not possible, then perhaps the monauralversions of these songs would have been preferable.  <br />There are certainly other changes I wish could have been made.  Personally, I have always hated &quot;The Ballad of John and Yoko,&quot; and I can't stand those horridly syrupy strings that Phil Spector added to Paul's lovely &quot;The Long and Winding Road.&quot;  There is an unadorned version of the song included in the final Beatles &quot;Anthology,&quot; and I would have loved to see it included here.  But then again, the whole point of the cd is that it includes the actual &quot;top forty&quot; versions of these songs, and that means sorry, no substitutions.<br />Overall, I love this cd, as it spans nearly the entirely of the Beatles' *oeuvre* in a single cd that delivers hit after hit after hit after hit. . . As a &quot;first Beatle album&quot; for someone born too late to hear this amazing group the first time around, this is a fine choice, indeed.
1563896656|4.0|The most lighthearted tale even written by acclaimed comicbook scribe, Alan Moore, is likely the League of Extraordinary Gentlemen. Moore borrows characters from famous works in Victorian Literature, including Mina Murray, Captain Nemo, the Invisible Man, Alan Quartermain, Dr. Jeckell and Mr. Hyde, and places them in a Justice League-type team, gathered together to find a stolen device capable of unleashing the horrors of aerial warfare on London. Moore constructs a dead-on parody of these high-flying romantic heroes; their stuffy attitudes and language; their utter political incorrectness; their obvious sexual hang-ups. Fans of Moore's darker work, such as Watchmen and From Hell, may be disappointed, but those of us who have read the rousing tails of adventure it masterfully parodies will find the League of Extraordinary Gentlemen entertaining and hilarious.
0393317552|2.0|Jared Diamond explains the differences between human societies but under-emphasizes an important factor. Randomness. Randomness in genes and natural events. I find it extremely difficult to believe that as human groups spread out across the globe they all had exactly the same IQ, physical abilities, etc. It is more likely that they were different from the start. Diamond tries to paint a picture where these differences were nonexistent. I've been in enough school classes where we dividided into groups to do the same project. At the end of the semester the diversity of the end results was amazing even though the groups were supposed to be identical in IQ, ability, etc.<br />It is highly likely that certain cultures ARE better than others. Their group gestalt was superior even in early times. Perhaps they gravitated to a particualry good leader. Perhaps they had a better notion of decision making, or curiosity, or whatever. Unfortunatley Diamond tries too hard not to offend with this probable truth.

B000002I2G|3.0|The Soft Parade is often unjustly criticized for being the most dreadfully commercial of the Doors' albums, largely by those who can not get over the album's first two tracks. I will admit, those songs are a lot to forgive. Backed by a mushy horn section, \\"Tell All the People\\" and \\"Touch Me\\" were everything the Doors thankfully were not. The songs were syrupy, banal, creatively sterile lounge-act imitations, invented only to please their record company's insistent request for more commercial material.<br />But simply writing off the Soft Parade because of those terribly misaimed attempts is to disregard twenty seven excellent minutes of the Doors' shadowy, blend of rock, blues and jazz. The remainder of the Soft Parade features several excellent examples of Doors trademarks such as earthy mysticism (\\"Wishful Sinful\\"), frothy blues-rollicking (\\"Wild Child\\") and smoky, spiraling jazziness (\\"Shaman's Blues,\\"). It also embraces more authentic adventurousness on tracks such as \\"Easy Ride\\" and \\"Runnin' Blue,\\" the band's first foray into country boogie and album's highlight, the title track, a cryptic, mood-shifting epic that condemns suburban, mid/upper-class cultural assimilation. The song features a fully charged Jim Morrison sounding simultaneously scathing and graceful. Although every song after track two is at least good, this is the only truly legendary moment of the album and a epic that surpasses \\"When the Music's Over\\" and even \\"The End.\\" When Morrison entices listeners with his authoritative, even frightening, chant of \\"You cannot petition the Lord with prayer!\\" the album's embarrassing opening pair of songs is quickly forgiven.

B00000J2SO|4.0|As in 1973, Ritchie was placed in a difficult quandary in 1979 to replace a singer who had epitomized the sound and style of his group. Although Rainbow never quite achieved the comparable global fame as Deep Purple, Dio's commanding presence had been every bit as integral to the band's image as Gillan's. Fortunately, in a successful repetition of six years earlier, Ritchie found an excellent singer in Graham Bonnet whose powerful voice befitted Rainbow just as effectively as Gillan's replacement David Coverdale suited Deep Purple. Unfortunately, while a capable album, Down to Earth does not attain the earlier heights of Burn. Whereas the latter signified a landmark progression in Purple's songwriting in heralding the increasingly mystical and Middle-Eastern dimension to Ritchie's music which culminated in an artistic zenith with Rainbow Rising, Bonnet's debut is a regression from Rainbow's prior albums. Nevertheless, what faults Down to Earth suffers are hardly a consequence of Bonnet himself; admittedly, the main reason this album scores four stars is especially due to his impassioned performance. Rather, the criticisms lie with Ritchie's choice to commercialize the music; a decision which, although only moderately damaging here, would eventually prove to be fatal. Thus, what results is an unusual, transitional Rainbow album mostly featuring pop metal while still retaining notable elements of the gothic Dio past. <BR> As the lavish expenses incurred in transporting the enormous computerized rainbow were undoubtedly a catalyst in inducing Ritichie to shift the music to a more mainstream direction, it entreats purists to speculate that had he jettisoned this cumbersome prop altogether, would the subsequent Rainbow albums have been written in the supernatural atmosphere of the Dio era? That in concert Ritchie still continued to perform many Dio tracks during the short lived Bonnet era invites puzzlement over his choice to change musical direction for the studio whilepleasing the fans with the old classics live. In any event, in listening to Down to Earth one cannot help but view it as a compromised album. Although the opening track &quot;All Night Long&quot; has a classic majestic riff reminiscent of &quot;Man on the Silver Mountain,&quot; the ensuing verse immediately indicates that Ritchie has eschewed his prior mysticism for pop sensibility. This marked shift is underscored in another uninspired track, &quot;Born to Lose&quot; which recalls lesser Deep Purple numbers on Who Do you Think we Are (not coincidental, as Roger Glover rejoined Ritchie after six years to become his Rainbow co-songwriter as with Purple) While &quot;Since You've Been Gone,&quot; has an infectiously catchy riff, it becomes increasingly tedious after a while, in sharp contrast to earlier sophisticated classics like &quot;Stargazer&quot; which retain their potency after numerous listenings.One can only imagine how bored Graham must be in still having to perform it at every single concert!  <BR> Allegedly one of the salient reasons why Graham was sacked shortly after this album's release pertained to his indolence in contributing lyrics; in retrospect, this is a pity for with MSG, Alcatrazz, and Impellitteri, Graham not only disciplined himself but proved to be an insightful lyricist tackling supernatural tales &quot;Desert Song,&quot; &quot;Kree Nakoorie&quot; and &quot;Leviathan;&quot; poignant recollections of childhood &quot;Starrcarr Lane;&quot; alcoholism in &quot;Too Drunk to Live, Too Drunk to Die,&quot; and &quot;Secret Lover;&quot; and finally incisive political commentary &quot;Hiroshima Mon Amour&quot; and &quot;White and Perfect.&quot; In any event, Graham's lyrics unquestionably would have been superior to Glover's prosaic offerings, which, apart from the critical exception of &quot;Eyes of the World,&quot; relate exclusively to love affairs. While Dio's lyrics peridocally offered incomplete stories with unfortunate verse repetitions, theywere a significant component to Rainbow's halcyon years in inspiring Ritchie to take his songwriting to unprecedented heights; their colorful atmosphere doubtlessly influenced him to craft songs which reflected their mythological content. In line with Ritchie's disposition to commercialization, Glover's tepid lyrics sadly  reinforced his songs to be competent but safe and unadventurous. With Dio, Rainbow was poised to take metal to a higher plane by carving its own niche of medieval flavored epic rock; after his departure, Ritchie's motives became far less ambitious in providing straightforward, entertaining rock. Indeed, this album's title suggests a more modest approach to songwriting in contrast to the previous Dio epics. <BR> With the negatives being said, it is time to dwell on the positives which ultimately outweigh them. &quot;Love's No Friend of Mine&quot; is an effective blues song, reminiscent of Mistreated, albeit on a smaller scale, and Lost in Hollywood features an ambitious neo-baroque interlude recalling Ritchie's still present but steadily declining classical affinity.  <BR>Nevertheless, the two finest songs on the album, &quot;Eyes of the World&quot; and &quot;Making Love,&quot; affirm that some vestiges of Rainbow's glorious past still lingered in Ritchie's songs. This is nowhere more apparent than on the former, an epic track which, apart from its lyrical content, easily have been penned during the Dio years. Powered by a signature Blackmore riff, it culminates in a slithering Middle-Eastern guitar interlude which stands as one of Ritchie's greatest solos. Glover's lyric likewise weaves a provocative political analysis, a stark and refreshing contrast to the otherwise tepid love themes which dominate virtually every other song. Don Airey is an exceptional keyboardist, but like the equally dextrous Tony Carey, he is underused with his role largely ancillary apart from a few brief shining solos in &quot;Eyes of the World&quot; and &quot;Lost in Hollywood.&quot; The album is enhanced by Glover's production which is overall sharper and cleaner than that of the Dio era; here the bass is  clearly audible and Ritchie's solos lash over the rhythm with more clarity. <BR> Nevertheless, the album's greatest asset is indisputably Graham Bonnet. Unlike future collaborations withYngwie and Impellitteri, Ritchie's songs better complement his style and grant his voice more space; here Graham gives what is perhaps his finest performance on vinyl, singing in a comfortable middle vocal range devoid of the high pitched screams which clearly strains his voice on subsequent albums. All in all, Down to Earth is a rewarding album showcasing Rainbow at a critical juncture in its career.

B00005RFQ5|1.0|In the 80's, Prince was a pioneer among pioneer's before him, reinventing pop culture &amp; setting a new standard 4 every artist during &amp; after our generation. Through the years, amidst line-up, musical &amp; even name changes, I've been able 2 conjure up enough spirit 2 gleefully call &amp; praise him the best pop artist of our century, offering us more than The King or The King Of Pop could ever muster up. <br />But, I guess in his own words of the song 'Sometimes It Snows In April'....'all good things they say never last'. This album is a jumble of a confused Prince, celebrating his newfound religion as a Jehovah's Witness (that means no more 'Darling Nikki' lyrics kiddies!) which he always tapped into spirituality, but he's gone way overboard. The jazzy, Mingus/Thelonius Monk stylings of the music will leave u feeling less like you're partying at the Glam Slam but more like you're suffocating in a smoke filled dive with a room full of beatniks.<br />There are tiny outbreaks of our beloved Purple One crawling out at times, but not enough 2 keep this fanatic who's stuck by &amp; at times even stuck up 4 him when naysayers said 'he was over'. Give me the Black Album or even the White Album (Lovesexy) anyday.<br />Do yourself a favor &amp; listen 2 this 1 b4 buying it...a lack of sales may finally be a wake-up call that we want the real Royalty Of Pop &amp; Rock 2 reclaim his crown!

B000003TAW|5.0|This is a supoib album lyrically and musically. It starts off with the quirky My Name Is Jonas, easily sing-a-longable and catchy. No One Else is not the most profound song, but stays tight and perfectly produced, in addition to Cuomo's great voice. The World Has Turned And Left Me Here features a great bass line and lyrics that almost anyone can relate too and one time or another. Buddy Holly is, no matter what anyone says, an awesome song. Everything here is perfect, and even the little nuances are perfect-- the hand claps, the background vocals, etc. The Sweater Song is the angriest peice on the album, but still hummable and funny in a dark way. Surf Wax America is angry too, but in a more &quot;subtle&quot; way-- Rivers sarcastically complaining about the rat race disguised as an innocent surfing song. Say It Ain't So is one of the best tracks, the chorus is just killer. It took a while for me to like In The Garage-- it's a sweet song but the tune is rather repetitive. Now we come to Holiday, probably my favourite song on the album. It's got such a great tune, and the words are fun to sing along with. It ends up with Only In Dreams, one of the most loved songs of all that =w= has released. It drags on a little but it is pretty, in a dark way. <br />In closing, this is an album that I would recommend to nearly anyone. In my opinion, it's just as good as the legendary &quot;Pinkerton&quot;. Not as serious, but has a good beat and you can sing to it.

B000002TYX|5.0|THE BEATLES ANTHOLOGY is the greatest retrospective overview of any group I have seen. In early 1994, the three remaining Beatles, Paul, George and Ringo, were give a cassette tape of demos made by their late bandmate John Lennon (who had died in 1980) that he had made in his home circa 1977. The three Beatles, nicknamed the \\"Threetles,\\" added overdubs onto the original recording to create a \\"new\\" Beatles recording, the first since 1970. They completed two of Lennon's uncompleted songs, \\"Free as a Bird,\\" and \\"Real Love.\\" The first was issued on this first Anthology album, the latter on the second album. These two new tracks are the backbone to the whole Anthology set. Besides the three albums, there are the two singles, FREE AS A BIRD and REAL LOVE, which each contain the title tracks, as well as three others; the Anthology book, over 300 pages, and the Anthology documentary, just recently released on DVD, with over 11 hours of footage.<BR>A warning to new fans: These Anthology albums do not have the original masters of The Beatles' songs that you would hear on the radio and may be searching for. These are outtakes, jam sessions, and live recordings of familiar favorites, as well as previously unreleased tracks. The first volume covers their early days, circa 1958, through late 1964. Volume two covers 1965 through early 1968. The final album covers 1968 through to the end, mid-1970. These albums are a great insight to the way the Beatles evolved and changed as musicians and are well worth the money, especially for the rare new songs.
B000002MG1|5.0|if there is one album that sums up r.e.m.'s career, this is it. poetic, moody, and profound, there is not a bad song on it. although some consider &quot;ignoreland&quot; the rotten apple that spoils the bunch.. it is more tongue-in-cheek. this was the album that really won people over into seeing r.e.m. as a band with pop power (&quot;shiny happy people&quot;) and true songwriting capability. this album is classic r.e.m., in the truest sense, particularly &quot;find the river&quot; and &quot;everybody hurts.&quot;

This (and the accompanying Blue album) are the only Beatles \\"greatest hits\\" albums, besides THE BEATLES 1, which is strictly No. 1 singles, rather than the debatable \\"best of...\\" While it is a good compilation, it still seems pointless to try to pick out the best of the Beatles.

B00000IQW0|5.0|The quality of the picture is great, the sound is OK, but then it was never originally intended to be Sci-Fi material.<br />The biggest problemn I have is that while claiming that the DVD is in \\"widescreen format\\", suggesting that they have preserved the entire image that would have been seen on a movie theater screen, they did nothing of the sort. Instead, all they did was lop off some of the bottom and the top of the screen, SUBTRACTING from the original image, resulting an a FAKE \\"widescreen\\" format. Therefore, you're actually getting LESS of the original image than if it were done in the normal full frame format. This is verified by comparing the DVD scenes with the normal video tape of the same film. <br />We can all argue whether or not we like the Widescreen format or not, but the idea of presenting a film in \\"widescreen\\" is to PRESERVE the entire image that was shot with a high aspect ratio, not remove some of the image from a film that was shot with the normal ratio!!! (...)
B000002UVX|5.0|Sometimes God graces us with individuals who are blessed with extraordinary talent. Jimi Hendrix was one of those people and this CD is a display of that extraordinary talent.    The first two songs , WHO KNOWS and MACHINE GUN , are from the first January 1, 1970 show while the rest is from the second show of that day. You can see the actual performances of both songs on the DVD \\"BAND OF GYPSYS : LIVE AT THE FILLMORE EAST\\" (although on WHO KNOWS they cut out Buddy Miles' scatting in the DVD)    You might as well call MACHINE GUN a classic. Everyone just loves this version of the song. Some people own this CD just to have this one version. Miles' vocals supplements perfectly into this song and Billy Cox gives an excellent steady bass groove. Hendrix's guitar solo on this is one of the greatest ever.    I also love the ending to WE GOTTA LIVE TOGETHER. The song here is greatly edited down from its original time. The unedited version is on the 2 disc cd's \\"LIVE AT THE FILLMORE EAST\\" As the pace began to build it was almost like Hendrix and Miles were having a race for the end of the song.     As time passes , sometimes , those who we once considered great suddenly become obsolete when compared to current artists. NOT HENDRIX. His work can stand up to any guitarist today even though he passed away in 1970. This man is still seen as the greatest among the greats. He was something special ; extraordinary. This CD is just further proof of it.

I'm a sure Miles Davis fan (and others) would say I'm wrong - but I think Brubeck set the bar and no one to date has been able to reach a higher level. This is the champagne of jazz . B00000K19E|2.0|The special effects in &quot;The Matrix&quot; were spellbinding.  Keanu Reeves and Laurence Fishburne weren't exactly suburb actors in the film, but they weren't exactly bad either.  But I feel this movie lacks one principle that makes a great movie: great writing.  Laurence Fishburne as Morpheus walks Neo (portrayed by Keanu Reeves) through a lot of discussion of what the matrix is, in the middle of the film.  This fits into the category of 'exposition', a definite problem with script writing.  It would have been better if the character Neo would have been involved with more drama while actually figuring out what the matrix is.  In a movie like &quot;Star Wars&quot;, the characters are placed in a setting unlike our world...&quot;In a galaxy far, far away.&quot;  The action in &quot;Star Wars&quot; moves from one scene to another without the characters stopping whatever they're doing, then sitting around and explaining how the Millennium Falcon jumps to light speed or how the Death Star destroys planets...the viewer actually sees the stars race across the screen as the Millennium Falcon gets away from the Empire fighters, and see how Princess Lea painfully watches her own planet get destroyed.  In &quot;The Matrix&quot;, besides the long scene that gets bogged down by exposition, there isn't much to character development.  If you take away all the amazing special effects, there wasn't that much in the script to hold the characters together.  I am bothered how this movie is considered a &quot;thinking man's sci-fi thriller&quot;.  After all I just said, I really didn't feel this movie lived up to that promise.

B00003CXFU|5.0|I think that almost everyone is familiar with this film version of how Erin Brokovitch took on a large corporation that had knowingly polluted the water supply of a small town, and through their intentional cover-up had adversely affected the health of almost everyone in that town. This is a true life David and Goliath story. Only, in this case, &quot;David's&quot; weapons were chutzpa, perseverance, cleavage, and a big dose of commitment to something she believed in, instead of a sling and a stone.<br />Brockovich was no dummy. To the contrary, as portrayed by Julia Roberts, (one of my favorite actresses!) she was bright, articulate (if a little earthy), and always aware of her impact on people. She had a natural empathy that people could feel. Consequently they liked her and responded to her. This applies, from what I've read, to the real life Brockovich, and certainly to the screen Brockovich. Julia Roberts' manner of dressing was, if anything, toned down a bit from that of the real life Erin Brockovich. For those who found Roberts' attire distracting, I wonder how you would have responded to the real Erin.<br />Albert Finney played her boss, a moderately successful &quot;shirt-sleeve&quot; attorney who had a lot to lose if the lawsuit went awry. He gave this role just the right blend of wit, concern, fear, anger, and elation. He's the attorney that we'd all like to find.<br />I found this movie to be entertaining, well acted, satisfying, and one that I can watch and watch with feeling so happy at the end. See it to know what I mean....
B00005QIPH|5.0|This is a great album: it's melodic every step of the way; it rocks with a staggering and really refreshing, up-beat energy.  I recommend it for anyone who prefers enjoying music to complaining about a perceived lack of innovation. That people who can bear to listen to the radio are digging this kind of pure rock and roll is all one could ask for.  Most of the people reading this, in fact, probably discovered Is This It on the radio or MTV, and I don't think you are very well-served by the previous reviews.  This is good music, and there's nothing tired about that -- and that it's good is not really anything that you need to be told.  What I will offer, what I feel is most useful to a new listener, is a list of other indie-pop albums that people I've known with no taste for indie-pop have enjoyed.  You should check them out, if you're interested in albums that have incredible, hard-rocking, melodic, intelligent songs from track 1 to track 12 -- the kind of thing you might imagine if your favorite moment of your favorite &quot;rock&quot; song were extended for 45 minutes:<br />Keep It Like a Secret - Built to Spill<BR>Terror Twilight - Pavement<BR>Emergency and I - Dismemberment Plan<BR>If You're Feeling Sinister - Belle and Sebastian<BR>Sophtware Slump - Grandaddy (especially if you liked OK Comp)<br />These aren't my favorites: these are just what I think you will be able to appreciate without any getting-used-to.<br />Rock and roll doesn't need any saving -- it's alive and well -- it just needs a little appreciation. 0812550706|5.0|Before reading this book i hated science fiction.  I loved fantasy  but i DESPISED science fiction.  I had never been able to find anything remotely decent.  I was not overly fond of H. G. Wells or Ray Bradbury, and no other &quot;classic&quot; sci fi books were of much interest to me.  That is, until i came to Orson Scott cars's book, Ender's Game.  It was my own fault for not reading it before, my brother owned a copy and urged me to read it.  Even strangers wanted me to read the book.  I was reading a Raymond E. Feist book in an airport, and some guy, a complete stranger came up to me and said that if i liked that, i should read Ender's Game.  I finally gave in, but my pre conceived notions were still too strong.  I read the first chapter and put it down, i could not get into it.  FINALLY, yet another person, a friend of mine also begged me to read it.  He admitted that the begginning had problems, but that it got much better later on.  I remember saying the same thing, in reference to both the Harry Potter books and the Lord of The Rings series: Some of The best books I have ever read.  I decided to tough it out, and read Ender's Game.  I made the mistake of picking it up at 10 o clock at night.  I was awake until three in the morning reading until I was forced to go to bed.  It was a fantastic book, and i eagerly finished the other books, Speaker For The Dead, Xenocide, Children Of The Mind, Ender's Shadow, and Shadow of the Hegemon, in less than 4 days each.  Even now I cant really find any Science Fiction I enjoy, though I have not gotten around to reading Anne Mcaffrey, whom is supposed to write great Sci-fi/Fantasy books.  I even tried 1984 and hated it.  The point that I am attempting to make, and you may be able to discern from my ramblings and endorsemnents of several other books, is that you dont need to have any particular love of Science Fiction to enjoy this book.
B000002QWD|5.0|I don't know if the record still holds up, but for more than 30 years, this Bing Crosby holiday album ranked as the best-selling Christmas album ever--and with good reason. 0679731725|5.0|The word dignity that concerns Stevens so in this novel comes from the latin dignitas &lt; dignus, worthy. This novel by Ishiguro is worthy of the Booker prize it recieved and much praise from all quarters. Like his previous two novels there is a strong theme here of realization of having backed the wrong horse ,so to speak, and how to proceed from there. This, Ishiguro's third effort, reaches masterpiece quality in form, prose, restraint, and narrative. A previous reviewer's comparison to Chekhov is very apt. Steven's the samurai slash english gentry butler of Darlington hall has spent his life serving what he thought was a great man, Lord Darlington. Darlington , it turns out was an unwitting pawn of the Nazi's in diplomacy between Nazi Germany and England. Steven's realizes this along with his missed romantic chances in his past and it breaks his heart. He must decide a worthy way to spend the remains of his day. Stevens although not a perfect human is a refreshing literary character with his selfless devotion, civility, and ideals. His struggle to learn how to banter and joke is the most touching and humorous part of the book. This is a modern day classic!

B00005QDW1|5.0|For those fans who are ONLY looking for &quot;Tragic Kingdom Part 2&quot; should skip right past No Doubt's latest release.  &quot;Rock Steady&quot; is the band's most experimental release to date, pushing away from a hard-core ska base onto a more radio-friendly, electronica/reggae/techno level. While listening to &quot;Rock Steady,&quot; you can definately recognize the usual No Doubt vibe, but this album gives your ears more twists and turns that many fans of &quot;Trapped in A Box&quot; and &quot;Don't Speak&quot; will not appreciate to the max.<br />The album begins with an &quot;Intro&quot; which lays down the chorus for the title track on the album.  Then, &quot;Hella Good,&quot; one of the most catchy, energetic tracks on the album pumps through your speakers.  &quot;Hella Good&quot; is some of No Doubt's best work to date, and its chorus remains in your head all day long.  Other tracks that follow the footsteps of &quot;Hella Good&quot; are &quot;Making Out,&quot; &quot;Detective,&quot; and &quot;In My Head.&quot;  <br />The new single, &quot;Hey Baby,&quot; foreshadows the new album perfectly because it mixes pop-influenced beats with R&amp;B influenced vocals.  Since Gwen teamed up with rapper Eve for the amazing track &quot;Let Me Blow Your Mind,&quot; it shows that her musical tastes are diversifying and expanding to other musical genres.  Gwen's duet with Moby, &quot;South Side,&quot; shows her choice to dive into the electronica wave that has captured many artists such as Madonna and Janet Jackson.  I have a lot of respect for bands who aren't afraid to experiment with their music to remain fresh.  It is not condsidered &quot;selling out,&quot; but an opportunity to branch out and experience new types out music while keeping an original sound as a basis.  No Doubt is a perfect example of a band who can shine through many different musical tastes.<br />Even though the whole album is worth a complete listen, songs like the Ric Ocasek produced &quot;Don't Let Me Down&quot; and the title track, &quot;Rock Steady,&quot; are incredible, along with the others I listed above.  However, the best song on the album is &quot;Waiting Room,&quot; a duet with Prince which has the whole package.  Its techno-influenced beats make the track one you can dance to, and it gives Gwen the opportunity to expand her vocal range unlike ever before.  Both Gwen and Prince collide together and connect perfectly on this track, and the chorus is incredibly catchy.<br />Once again, &quot;Rock Steady&quot; is simply a unique album for No Doubt that can do no wrong.  The energy that the whole band holds throughout each song is unlike any of their other efforts.  Even though both &quot;Tragic Kingdom&quot; and &quot;Return of Saturn&quot; are solid releases, I believe this album is the epitomy of No Doubt's best musical work to date.  This style is unlike the two albums before &quot;Tragic Kingdom,&quot; too, but it is definately talent-influenced music.  If you are a No Doubt fan and OPEN-MINDED, do not be afraid.  &quot;Rock Steady&quot; will give you everything you need to quench your &quot;No Doubt fix&quot; and then some.  However, if you only like the band for their previous efforts, then remain thirsty and wait for the new Limp Bizkit CD.

B00000613T|5.0|I have been waiting all my life for a performance of Mahler's Ninth such as this.  The &quot;over-interpretation&quot; of Mahler is a sticky argument that we could spend the rest of our lives arguing over, just let me say, I love Bernstein and his highly emotional and charged recordings of the Ninth.  But Boulez allows us to truly understand the genius of Mahler's writing and orchestration.  Every line is clean and unlike the intense dynamic extremes in other recordings of Mahlher's symphonies I've heard that might sound good in a live hall, this studio recording is clear from start to finish with an ambience that doesn't try to manipulate the sound, or for that matter, the audience.  The opening andante is one of the most beautiful versions I have heard.  Even and crisp, the opening motif speaks for itself, without the &quot;emotional&quot; tweaking many conductors try to milk out of it.  The way the opening motif is written, why mess around with it?  Mahler's genius stands alone.  The sentimentality and the plaintive tone of the composition is in the notes.  In fact, after listening to Boulez's version, many other recordings (including my old favorite Bernstein's) seem maudlin and less profound because of this.  I don't believe one can be right or wrong in their opinion of this piece, it is expansive enough to cover a wide range of interpretations, but I am of the &quot;anti-SWOON&quot; school of classical music.  Call it cold, but it moves me.  I love subtext and don't need everything explained to me.

B00004X01U|4.0|Before you freak out about the cd cover, Madonna has not gone country. In fact, this is Madonna's \\"real\\" dance album since her debut. Gone is the operatic voice, clunky electronic music, and \\"I'm the Mother of Spirituality\\" image. Now she is a forty year old mother, who still can hang out with the weirdos, the gays and the club kids late at night.<br />Music: Thanks to Madonna's new producer, French DJ Mirwais, the music is a lot more stripped down and acoustic guitar driven. Suprisingly, William Orbit changes his sound to a more 60's, 70's rock sound, but with a dance groove. At times the synth oriented sounds can be emotionally cold and distant but it still raises the bar of what American pop can do.<br />Voice: Madonna forgets her \\"Evita\\" voice lessons and goes back to a more plaintive, naked style reminescent of her \\"True Blue\\" stage. She uses effects on some of the up-tempo tracks, but on \\"I Deserve It\\" and \\"Gone\\" her singing is dry with just electronic squiggles and a guitar. It just proves that a person doesn't need to have a 5 million octave voice to show emotions.<BR>  <br />Lyrics: Even though this is a dance album, the lyrics are not generic. \\"Don't Tell Me\\" expresses her resistance of quitting her day job, \\"What It Feels Like For A Girl\\" talks about how unfairly treated women and girls are in society, and \\"I Deserve It\\" tells of her new \\"Guy\\". It's her best love song since \\"Take A Bow\\". But the best lyric-driven song is \\"Nobody's Perfect\\". It's her plea for her former lover to forgive her. Her most convincing \\"please forgive me song\\".<br />Standout Tracks: \\"Music\\" is a 70's funk tune whose simplicity is quite surprising. With all the bombastics of pop music today this basic dance song is a great welcome. It's chorus will be stuck in your mind for days. \\"I Deserve It\\" is just her dry voice, a guitar and electronic squiggles which gives the song a more personal feel. \\"Amazing\\" (where Madonna's voice shines)is a 60's esque brit-pop song that will make you dance. \\"Don't Tell Me\\" is a strange combination of dance, club, pop, and country. In your head you'll think, \\" What the world is this?\\", but you'll never stop dancing to it. I could go on and on, but i only have the maxium of 1,000 words.<BR> <BR>Recommend: Yes. If you like Madonna' s chamelon like music or if you like dance music. :)

The author writes of Griet (the subject of Vermeer's famous painting) in such a unique and versatile way, which makes her someone we all can identify with.  A work of fiction written with such substance and conviction one believes this story has to have been real.  This is a book for anyone who loves to read, with the slightest appreciation for the arts and history.  In today's world, there's a desire to regress to a time when things seemed to be more simple, and this book displays that time nor any amount of technological advances will ever change what is essential to human life - love and family.
B00004TJLD|5.0|NO whining about it not being &quot;as advertised&quot;.  Amazon is the party not being clear about this, other retail sites make it very clear as to the product you're purchasing.  It's a DAD version, not DVD-A, which means no 5:1.  Also, to hear it fully, you'll need a DVD player that handles 24bit/96khz.  Older DVD players will play it but at 48khz.<br />And this version is significantly better than any of the MFSL versions out there.  The MFSL version doesn't have the bass depth of even the regular Arista CD version although it is obviously cleaner sounding.  This DAD version makes up for that problem and really shines when on songs like &quot;Don't Let It Show&quot;, &quot;The Voice&quot;, and &quot;Total Eclipse&quot; where you get some of the cleanest sound keyboards to be heard on stereo.  If you sit down and listen to the MFSL version to this side-by-side with the DAD version, you'll hear all kinds of differences and be able to hear some of the layers that just got lost in the past.<br />This version is well worth purchasing even if you have various other versions of the album.  And if you haven't purchased it, if you like prog rock, this album is one of the best.

While in X-men, he was a somewhat coarse and wild, yet principled &quot;wildman, &quot; here he plays a totally genteel, polished gentleman whose straightforward honesty and candor make the girls who meet him just wriggle with romantic ecstasy, while inspiring nobler sentiments in the men.<br />There's only one short scene where time travel is really batted around. The rest of the film is a fun, not overdone exploration of how a gentleman from the past would respond to our contemporary world. And, without ruining the ending, it makes us nostalgic for the simple courtesies and chivalries of the past. At one point though, when feeling this, I also realized that it left out the harsh realities-- that back in time, there were a good proportion of cretinously sexist, racist, ignorant, wealthy pigs. Jackman is playing an idealized male romantic hero, as one might find in a Harlequin romance.<br />I also really enjoyed the role played by Liev Schreiber, the besieged (ala One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest&quot; by psychiatry discoverer of the time warp which made this story possible.<br />There are a number of magical moments in the story-- and it's magic which melts the heart and pulls those heartstrings for which we pay the eight bucks to see the movie on the big screen.<br />This is light fare, and sometimes, the light-fare genre just hits the spot. 0783225849|5.0|Alfred Hitchcock's classic thriller is often credited with fathering the modern slasher flick, but it must be kept in mind that this top-notch film is far more than that.  The innovative plot structure, which can never be repeated with the same effect, is a masterful way of making the viewer empathize with the victim and feel the shock and loss of murder.  Too many of the films that followed chose to empathize with the killer.  This is a crucial difference that allows Hitchcock's film to retain a certain humane quality, even as terrible things are happening on-screen.

0393312836|5.0|A Clockwork Orange has been reguarded as one of the best contemporary classics of today.  It is the story of Alex, a member of a gang in a future Britain.  Alex goes around amassing destruction, robbery, rape, and murder to his criminal record before being betrayed and sent to jail, where he undergoes a controversial treatment.<br />This treatment is a basic exercise of Pavlov's conditioning in which Alex is taught to hate everything he loves, so that he could leave the institute within two weeks of arriving there.  Unfortunately, nothing turns out the way Alex wanted.<br />A Clockwork Orange is a very good book on realizing why we are the way we are.  Because of Alex's loss of choice, we learn through Burgess a great deal about how being able to do bad things is so important.<br />The only deterrent to reading this book is the amount of violence, drug-taking, rape, and other things that might be found on a FOX tv show, which were banned worldwide at the time it was published, in the 1950's.  If you thought Catcher in the Rye was a immoral book, I wouldn't recommend this, but for those who can stomach the violence to realize the point are well worthy of reading this book.<br />This version of A Clockwork Orange is almost the same as the American version, except that it has a foreword written by Burgess himself, as well as the last chapter which was not published in America.  This book is a very good read, and a great addition to the avid reader's library.<br />Two thumbs up!

The album works for me for many reasons, particularly because of the open-air, spontaneous feel (quite the antithesis of heavily \\"produced\\" offerings like \\"Sgt. Pepper\\", et. al.), and the great contribution from ol' buddy Billy Preston who brings some much needed bounce and funk to the arrangements - his electric piano adds icing to the cake on \\"Get Back\\" and \\"I've Got A Feeling\\".
